messageBody:
Roger Milla wrote:

> Hi,
> i am a beginner in testing stuffs and i needs ur help teting this skins
> of methods using junit4 and mock object(actually easymock) because i
> read somewhere that
> it make test devellopement quick and simple. I'm also newbie with the
> concept of stubs and i basicaly know how to use expectations
> this is the skin of methods :
>
> public boolean contains(String userName, String password){
> boolean result = false;
> if(password == null || userName == null){
> return false;
> }
> for(User p:this.userSet) {
> if(p.getAccount().equalsIgnoreCase(userName) &&
> p.getPsswd().equals(password)) {
> result = true;
> break;
> }
> }
>
> return result;
> }
>
> where "this.userSet" is a generics List. This method is called from
> another class that just know about the two parameters.

If you are new to testing in general, then I recommend you ignore mocks
for now and instead try to test this method by observing what it does
and comparing that to what you expect. If you read more articles, many
authors call this "state-based testing", because you check the end state
of the object you're testing.

Thinking of your feature, I see the following test scenarios
immediately, but there might be more:

1. password is null
2. userName is null
3. userName and password found in this.userSet
4. userName found, but password doesn't match
5. userName not found
6. userName matches with "case insensitive match" and password matches

So I would write each test the best way I can. Let me write the first
two for you:

@Test public void userNameCannotBeNull() {
assertFalse(yourObject.contains(null, "ignored password"));
}

@Test public void passwordCannotBeNull() {
assertFalse(yourObject.contains("ignored user name", null));
}

For the case where the user name and password are found, can you give
your object (I'll call it a UserRegistry, since that is what I would
call it if I designed it) the userSet to operate with? I think of
something like this:

@Test public void foundUser() {
Set validUsers = new HashSet();
validUsers.add(new User("jbrains", "magic password"));
UserRegistry registry = new UserRegistry(validUsers);

assertTrue(registry.contains("jbrains", "magic password"));
}

After this, the "case insensitive" test is easy.

@Test public void foundUserWithCaseInsensitiveMatch() {
Set validUsers = new HashSet();
validUsers.add(new User("jbrains", "magic password"));
UserRegistry registry = new UserRegistry(validUsers);

assertTrue(registry.contains("JBRAINS", "magic password"));
}

Do you now see how to write the other two tests? Good luck.
